articles.headline: A Two-Step Plan to Stop Hackers
articles.snippet: You may not be able to keep your digital credentials from being stolen, but there are options for keeping a cyberthief from using them successfully.
articles.abstract: You may not be able to keep your digital credentials from being stolen, but there are options for keeping a cyberthief from using them successfully.
articles.lead_paragraph: There are a number of ways that consumers could react to the news this week that Russian hackers got their hands on 1.2 billion username and password combinations.

articles.headline: Court Rejects Deal on Hiring in Silicon Valley
articles.snippet: A judge rejected a settlement in a case that accuses tech companies of agreeing not to solicit one another’s employees.
articles.abstract: A judge rejected a settlement in a case that accuses tech companies of agreeing not to solicit one another’s employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — There is “ample evidence” that Silicon Valley was engaged in “an overarching conspiracy” against its own employees, a federal judge said on Friday, and it should either pay dearly or have its secrets exposed at trial.

articles.headline: Cashew Juice, the Apple of Pepsi’s Eye
articles.snippet: While farmers in India once left cashew apples to rot, some are now selling them as the source of what Pepsi hopes could be the next coconut water.
articles.abstract: While farmers in India once left cashew apples to rot, some are now selling them as the source of what Pepsi hopes could be the next coconut water.
articles.lead_paragraph: RATNAGIRI DISTRICT, India — When the cashew harvest starts here, the orchards clinging to the lush, wrinkled hills are blanketed by a brilliant yellow, orange and red carpet, created after farmers pluck the nut and toss its stem to the ground. There, the cashew apples, as the stems are known, quickly rot, except for a few used to brew a local spirit called feni that is popular in neighboring Goa.

articles.headline: Yields on 10-Year Treasuries Fall, Confounding the Experts
articles.snippet: The 10-year Treasury note fell to 2.42 percent with some analysts contending the decline was a response to current events.
articles.abstract: The 10-year Treasury note fell to 2.42 percent with some analysts contending the decline was a response to current events.
articles.lead_paragraph: The mantra in the bond market over the last several years has been that yields will inevitably rise. From time to time, that has even been true. But not lately, and especially not on Friday.

articles.headline: Fear of ‘Another Benghazi’ Drove White House to Airstrikes in Iraq
articles.snippet: Interviews with multiple officials in the Obama administration paint a portrait of a president forced by the unexpectedly rapid deterioration of security in Iraq to abandon his longstanding reluctance to use military force.
articles.abstract: Interviews with multiple officials in the Obama administration paint a portrait of a president forced by the unexpectedly rapid deterioration of security in Iraq to abandon his longstanding reluctance to use military force.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On Wednesday evening, moments after finishing a summit meeting with African leaders at the State Department, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff delivered a stark message to President Obama as they rode back to the White House in Mr. Obama’s limousine.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler, Alissa J. Rubin, Mark Mazzetti and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Iraq Airstrikes May Continue for Months, Obama Says
articles.snippet: President Obama sought to prepare Americans for an extended presence in the skies over Iraq, saying the airstrikes he ordered last week, which continued Saturday, could last months.
articles.abstract: President Obama sought to prepare Americans for an extended presence in the skies over Iraq, saying the airstrikes he ordered last week, which continued Saturday, could last months.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama said on Saturday that the airstrikes and humanitarian assistance drops he ordered last week in Iraq could go on for months, preparing Americans for an extended military presence in the skies there as Iraq’s leaders try to build a new government.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Tim Arango

articles.headline: A Corporate Tax Break That’s Closer to Home
articles.snippet: By allowing a telecom company to spin off part of itself into a real estate investment trust, the I.R.S. has opened a window to a way for many corporations to have lower tax bills.
articles.abstract: By allowing a telecom company to spin off part of itself into a real estate investment trust, the I.R.S. has opened a window to a way for many corporations to have lower tax bills.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rage is rising over American corporations that chop their tax bills by acquiring entities in lower-tax countries. Medtronic, AbbVie and Mylan have all announced such plans — known as inversions — in recent months. And Walgreen was poised to relocate to Switzerland after it completes its purchase of Alliance Boots, but did an about-face last week in the face of widespread denunciation.

articles.headline: When She Talks, Banks Shudder
articles.snippet: In a quest for tougher rules on banking, Anat R. Admati, an industry gadfly, is rapidly gaining a broader audience.
articles.abstract: In a quest for tougher rules on banking, Anat R. Admati, an industry gadfly, is rapidly gaining a broader audience.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bankers are nearly unanimous on the subject of Anat R. Admati, the Stanford finance professor and persistent industry gadfly: Her ideas are wildly impractical, bad for the American economy and not to be taken seriously.

articles.headline: Oversize Expectations for the Airbus A380
articles.snippet: Why is the giant A380 jet wowing passengers, but not many airlines? Its maker may have made the wrong bet on air travel’s future.
articles.abstract: Why is the giant A380 jet wowing passengers, but not many airlines? Its maker may have made the wrong bet on air travel’s future.
articles.lead_paragraph: To get a sense of the Airbus A380’s size and ambition, walk up the grand staircase of an Emirates version of the aircraft, past the showers and the first-class suites and then through endless rows in business class to the bar at the back of the upper deck. This sleek semicircle, alluringly underlit and fully stocked with pricey spirits like Grey Goose vodka, is undoubtedly one of the defining features of this aircraft, which can hold more than 500 passengers. The plane dwarfs every commercial jet in the skies.

articles.headline: For Refugees on Mountain, ‘No Water, Nothing’
articles.snippet: After fleeing from ISIS, the Yazidis, a tiny religious minority, are caught up in a larger refugee disaster occurring across Iraq, one that is hitting Kurdistan especially hard.
articles.abstract: After fleeing from ISIS, the Yazidis, a tiny religious minority, are caught up in a larger refugee disaster occurring across Iraq, one that is hitting Kurdistan especially hard.
articles.lead_paragraph: FISHKHABOUR, Iraq — Amid the low scrub on Mount Sinjar in northern Iraq, new piles of loose stones mark a bleak landscape: makeshift graves for scores, perhaps hundreds, of Yazidis, left behind by survivors desperate to find an escape from the Sunni militant fighters chasing them.

articles.headline: Tracing Ebola’s Breakout to an African 2-Year-Old
articles.snippet: The current Ebola outbreak, the largest ever, seems likely to surpass all previous known Ebola outbreaks combined, and epidemiologists predict it will take months to control.
articles.abstract: The current Ebola outbreak, the largest ever, seems likely to surpass all previous known Ebola outbreaks combined, and epidemiologists predict it will take months to control.
articles.lead_paragraph: Patient Zero in the Ebola outbreak, researchers suspect, was a 2-year-old boy who died on Dec. 6, just a few days after falling ill in a village in Guéckédou, in southeastern Guinea. Bordering Sierra Leone and Liberia, Guéckédou is at the intersection of three nations, where the disease found an easy entry point to the region.
articles.byline: By Denise Grady and Sheri Fink

articles.headline: Uniting to Take Congress, G.O.P. Tries to Become the Party of ‘Yes’
articles.snippet: With control of Congress within reach, party leaders say that Republicans will need to be realistic about what they can achieve and that a high level of party unity will be essential.
articles.abstract: With control of Congress within reach, party leaders say that Republicans will need to be realistic about what they can achieve and that a high level of party unity will be essential.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With control of Congress within reach, Republicans are quietly assembling an aggressive 2015 agenda built around a push for a balanced budget and quick passage of measures, like approval of the Keystone XL pipeline and repeal of a medical equipment tax, to show they can govern.

articles.headline: Capitalizing on U.S. Bombing, Kurds Retake Iraqi Towns
articles.snippet: As Kurdish officials said they were making advances against Sunni militants, Iraq's political crisis deepened, with a deadline expiring for the president to choose a nominee for prime minister.
articles.abstract: As Kurdish officials said they were making advances against Sunni militants, Iraq's political crisis deepened, with a deadline expiring for the president to choose a nominee for prime minister.
articles.lead_paragraph: GWER, Iraq — With American strikes beginning to show clear effects on the battlefield, Kurdish forces counterattacked Sunni militants in northern Iraq on Sunday, regaining control of two strategic towns with aid from the air.
articles.byline: By Rod Nordland and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: China’s Energetic Enforcement of Antitrust Rules Alarms Foreign Firms
articles.snippet: The increasing application of antimonopoly laws, against companies like Microsoft and Qualcomm, has raised concern in boardrooms around the world.
articles.abstract: The increasing application of antimonopoly laws, against companies like Microsoft and Qualcomm, has raised concern in boardrooms around the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — When almost 100 government antitrust investigators simultaneously marched into four of Microsoft’s offices across China late last month, they were not looking for tea and gossip.
articles.byline: By Neil Gough, Chris Buckley and Nick Wingfield

articles.headline: Print Is Down, and Now Out
articles.snippet: The persistent financial demands of Wall Street have trumped the informational needs of Main Street. Print has become too much of a drag on earnings, so media companies are dividing back up and print is being kicked to the curb.
articles.abstract: The persistent financial demands of Wall Street have trumped the informational needs of Main Street. Print has become too much of a drag on earnings, so media companies are dividing back up and print is being kicked to the curb.
articles.lead_paragraph: A year ago last week, it seemed as if print newspapers might be on the verge of a comeback, or at least on the brink of, well, survival.

articles.headline: An Audacious Studio Rattles Hollywood
articles.snippet: Red Granite Pictures, which produced “The Wolf of Wall Street,” is known for ambitious plans, exotic connections and a tangled legal history.
articles.abstract: Red Granite Pictures, which produced “The Wolf of Wall Street,” is known for ambitious plans, exotic connections and a tangled legal history.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — Christopher J. McFarland and Riza Shahriz Abdul Aziz, co-owners of Red Granite Pictures, which produced “The Wolf of Wall Street,” are stalking someone bigger than that film’s hero, the stock hustler Jordan Belfort.

articles.headline: Harper’s Publisher Standing Firm in His Defense of Print and Paywall
articles.snippet: John R. MacArthur, of Harper’s Magazine, is part of a small group of publishers who say they believe that the Internet is bad for writers and readers.
articles.abstract: John R. MacArthur, of Harper’s Magazine, is part of a small group of publishers who say they believe that the Internet is bad for writers and readers.
articles.lead_paragraph: When John R. MacArthur, the publisher of Harper’s Magazine and a zealous promoter of the virtues of print journalism, sits down at his desk to write, he has three options — a typewriter, an ancient beige PC and a modern Apple desktop computer.

articles.headline: 50 Million New Reasons BuzzFeed Wants to Take Its Content Far Beyond Lists
articles.snippet: The viral media site will use a $50 million investment to diversify its content, expand its video arm and create an in-house incubator for new technology.
articles.abstract: The viral media site will use a $50 million investment to diversify its content, expand its video arm and create an in-house incubator for new technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: Here are three completely crazy insights about BuzzFeed, the viral content start-up:

articles.headline: Simplifying the Bull: How Picasso Helps to Teach Apple’s Style
articles.snippet: The tech company’s highly secretive internal training program is like its products: meticulously planned, with polished presentations and a gleaming veneer that masks a great deal of effort.
articles.abstract: The tech company’s highly secretive internal training program is like its products: meticulously planned, with polished presentations and a gleaming veneer that masks a great deal of effort.
articles.lead_paragraph: CUPERTINO, Calif. — Apple may well be the only tech company on the planet that would dare compare itself to Picasso.

articles.headline: Midterms Give Parties Chance for Sweeping Control of States
articles.snippet: Republicans, who already control 55 percent of all state legislative seats, aim to pick off about a half-dozen chambers in elections this year and enact policies that can get no traction in Washington.
articles.abstract: Republicans, who already control 55 percent of all state legislative seats, aim to pick off about a half-dozen chambers in elections this year and enact policies that can get no traction in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — It was over 100 degrees here the other evening, but inside a buzzing office tucked away on a stretch of gun stores and pornography shops, Democrats were staring into computer screens and talking urgently into cellphones. The stakes were high: The Nevada Senate, which Democrats control by a single seat, could very well shift into Republican hands after November.

articles.headline: U.S. Actions in Iraq Fueled Rise of a Rebel
articles.snippet: Most of the political changes that fueled the fight of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the self-appointed caliph of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, were born directly from some American action.
articles.abstract: Most of the political changes that fueled the fight of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the self-appointed caliph of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, were born directly from some American action.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — When American forces raided a home near Falluja during the turbulent 2004 offensive against the Iraqi Sunni insurgency, they got the hard-core militants they had been looking for. They also picked up an apparent hanger-on, an Iraqi man in his early 30s whom they knew nothing about.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Iraqis Nominate Maliki Successor, Causing Standoff
articles.snippet: The Iraqi president nominated the Shiite leader Haider al-Abadi to replace Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, who has demanded to remain in power.
articles.abstract: The Iraqi president nominated the Shiite leader Haider al-Abadi to replace Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, who has demanded to remain in power.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Under heavy pressure from the United States, Iraqi lawmakers took a significant step on Monday by choosing a replacement for Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, widely blamed for their country’s polarized politics. But Mr. Maliki angrily rejected the move, vowing to fight in the courts and perhaps by use of force, throwing the country into new uncertainty even as it fights an onslaught by Sunni militants.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango, Alissa J. Rubin and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: F.B.I. Steps In Amid Unrest After Police Kill Missouri Youth
articles.snippet: The agency opened a civil rights inquiry into the fatal shooting of an unarmed black teenager as protests went into their third day in a St. Louis suburb.
articles.abstract: The agency opened a civil rights inquiry into the fatal shooting of an unarmed black teenager as protests went into their third day in a St. Louis suburb.
articles.lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — The F.B.I. on Monday opened a civil rights inquiry into the fatal shooting by a police officer of an unarmed black teenager here as protests bubbled into a third night in this St. Louis suburb.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman and Erica Goode
